title: tidyverse example
text:
This example uses library(tidyverse). See What is the tidyverse? by Joseph Rickert for an overview of tidyverse.
Code example is from the quarto chapter of R for Data Science.
We have data about 53940 diamonds. Only 126 are larger than 2.5 carats. The distribution of the remainder is shown below:

smaller |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = carat)) + 
  geom_freqpoly(binwidth = 0.01)

title: R Snippets with Rendered Chart Example
text:
Simple example of using R snippets to show a chart.
This ggplot example is built from the quarto documentation.

title: R Snippets with Rendered Chart Example
text:
Air Quality
Figure¬†1 further explores the impact of temperature on ozone level.

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(airquality, aes(Temp, Ozone)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(method = "loess")




Figure¬†1: Temperature and ozone level.





The sample blog template also comes with a simple R system addition test.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: knitr kable for table formatting
text:
This example uses knitr kable for additional table formatting.

df <- data.frame(player = c('AJ', 'Bob', 'Chad', 'Dan', 'Eric', 'Frank'),
                 position = c('A', 'B', 'B', 'B', 'B', 'A'),
                 points = c(1, 2, 2, 1, 0, 0))

#view data frame
knitr::kable(df[1:6, ], )




player
position
points




AJ
A
1


Bob
B
2


Chad
B
2


Dan
B
1


Eric
B
0


Frank
A
0

title: About
text:
The goal of the R Consortium Infrastructure Steering Committee (ISC) is to support projects that broadly help the R community. This might be software development, developing new teaching materials, documenting best practices, standardizing APIs or doing research. Currently, the ISC chiefly provides financial support for projects proposed by individuals or teams who have the skills to carry out the work.
You can apply to the ISC Grant Program here.
In this blog, we are interested in showcasing work and ideas that is help defining the direction of R. That means you! ü´µ This blog is a growing collection of voices from the R community, showing what‚Äôs possible with R and where it is headed. You are not required to be a grant recipient.
If you would like to particpate, please contact the R Consortium! info@r-consortium.org

summary(cars)

title: interactive dygraphs, Plot, knitr kable, LaTeX Example with TOC
text:
Plot Output
You can also embed plots, for example:


Code
library(ggplot2)
dat <- data.frame(cond = rep(c("A", "B"), each=10),
                  xvar = 1:20 + rnorm(20,sd=3),
                  yvar = 1:20 + rnorm(20,sd=3))

ggplot(dat, aes(x=xvar, y=yvar)) +
    geom_point(shape=1) + 
    geom_smooth() 





Figure¬†1: Pressure




Note that the code-fold: true parameter was added to the code chunk to hide the code by default (click ‚ÄúCode‚Äù above the plot to see the code).
The use of the label and fig-cap options make this a cross-referenceable figure (see Figure¬†1).

title: interactive dygraphs, Plot, knitr kable, LaTeX Example with TOC
text:
Interactivity
You can also add interactive plots. For example:

library(dygraphs)
dygraph(nhtemp) %>% 
  dyRangeSelector(dateWindow = c("1920-01-01", "1960-01-01"))




Figure¬†2: New Haven Temperatures

title: interactive dygraphs, Plot, knitr kable, LaTeX Example with TOC

Tables

knitr::kable(head(ggplot2::diamonds))

title: interactive dygraphs, Plot, knitr kable, LaTeX Example with TOC
text:
LaTeX Math
You can also include LaTeX math:

P\left(A=2\middle|\frac{A^2}{B}>4\right)
